facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 624 of 1971 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated 8th April 1970 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P.A. No. 433/1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 624 of 1971. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and order dated the 8th April, 1970 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P.A. No. 433/1969.

facts.text: Prior to 15th July 1964, there were two separate services in Punjab: Provincial Civil Medical Service (PCMS) and Public Health Service, each with Class I and Class II.

anchor.surface_text: There were, in the State of Punjab prior to 15th July, 1964, two separate and independent services, namely, Provincial Civil Medical Service  hereinafter for the sake of brevity referred to as PCMS  and Public Health Service.

facts.text: Appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh were District Medical Officers of Health in Class II of Public Health Service until promotion with retrospective effect from 25th April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Both services companyprised two classes, Class I and Class II, and each had its own separate ranking for seniority and channel of promotion. The post of District Medical Officer of Health was a post in Class 11 of the Public Health Service

facts.text: Dr. Jagjit Singh was senior to the appellant in rank.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and one Dr. Jagjit Singh were, until their promotion with retrospective effect from 25th April, 1964, District Medical Officers of Health in Class II of Public Health Service. Dr. Jagjit Singh was admittedly senior to the appellant in rank.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were promoted from Class II of PCMS to Class I PCMS by order dated 8th April 1964 with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents, Nos. 3 to 19 were until their promotion by an order dated 8th April, 1964, in Class II of PCMS. It appea rs that some posts in Class I of PCMS fell vacant and it was, therefore, decided to make promotions to these posts from amongst officers belonging to Class II of PCMS and an order dated 8th April, 1964 was accordingly issued by the State Government.

facts.text: The promotion order for Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 dated 8th April 1964 was conveyed to them on 23rd April 1964, and they assumed charge between 27th April 1964 and 11th May 1964.

anchor.surface_text: promoting inter alia respondents Nos. 3 to 19 to Class 1, PCMS with immediate effect. Though this order was made on 8th April, 1964, it companyld number be companyveyed to respondents Nos. 3 to 19 until 23rd April, 1964 and respondents Nos. 3 to 19 companyld, therefore, assume charge of the higher posts of promotion only after 27th April, 1964.

facts.text: PCMS and Public Health Service were integrated with effect from 15th July 1964, creating combined PCMS Class I and Class II cadres.

anchor.surface_text: This was the position which obtained when PCMS and Public Health Service were integrated as part of the administrative reorganisation of the State Medical and Health Department with effect from 15th July, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant was appointed to work in the post of Assistant Director Health Services on his own pay scale from 25th April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant are companycerned, Dr. Jagjit Singh was on deputation with the Defence Department, while the appellant was appointed to work- in the post of Assistant Director Health Services on his own pay scale from 25th April, 1964.

facts.text: State Government promoted appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh to Assistant Director with retrospective effect from 25th April 1964 by order dated 24th July 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companysidered the representation of the appellant and decided that the appellant should be given promotion to the post of Assistant Director with effect from 25th April, 1964. But Dr. Jagjit Singh was senior to the appellant in the cadre of District Medical Officers of Health and it would, therefore, be unfair to him to ignore his claim and give promotion to the appellant who was his junior.

facts.text: State Government memorandum dated 25th October 1965 laid down principle for inter se seniority: length of continuous service from date of appointment in the group, subject to not disturbing parent seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government by a memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 decided that the inter se seniority of officers belonging to the two integrating services should be determined on the following principle vide clause 2 ii  The seniority,of Deputy Directors and Assistant Directors on the cadre of the Public Health on integration in PCMS-1 should be determined with reference to the length of companytinuous service from the date of appointment in the group subject to the companydition that the seniority of a person in parent seniority list will number be disturbed.,,

facts.text: State Government order dated 4th December 1967 determined seniority of Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 from date of their order of appointment, 8th April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government, however, issued an order dated 4th December, 1967 determining that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date, of their order of appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 irrespective as to when they assumed charge of their respective posts and on this basis, rejected the claim of the appellant.

facts.text: Provisional joint seniority list of PCMS Class I published by State Government showed Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 senior to appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, a provisional joint seniority list of PCMS Class I was published by the State Government and in this list, respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were shown as senior to Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 226 in Punjab and Haryana High Court challenging the seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant being aggrieved by the decision of the State Government giving seniority to respondents Nos. 3 to 19 over Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant, filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Punjab and Haryana challenging the seniority list published by the State Government.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge of High Court allowed the writ petition and directed revision of seniority list to place appellant senior to Respondents Nos. 3 to 19.

anchor.surface_text: This ground was accepted by the learned Single Judge who heard the petition and taking the view that Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant were senior to respondents Nos. 3 to 19 the learned Single Judge allowed the petition and directed that the seniority list should revised by the State Government so as to give seniority to the appellant over respondents Nos. 3 to 19.

facts.text: State Government and Director of Health Services filed Letters Patent Appeal No. 446 of 1969; some Respondents filed LPA No. 433 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government and the Director of Health Services, Punjab thereupon preferred Letters Patent Appeal No. 446 of 1969 before a Division Bench of the High Court. Some of the respondents Nos. 3 to 19 also preferred separate letters Patent Appeal No. 433 of 1969.

facts.text: Division Bench of Punjab Haryana High Court allowed the Letters Patent Appeals and upheld the provisional joint seniority list.

anchor.surface_text: Both these Letters Patent Appeals were heard by a Division Bench of the High Court. The learned Judges companystituting the Division Bench took the view that the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 laid down the principle determining seniority only for Deputy Directors and Assistant Directors in the Public Health Service on integration in PCMS Class I ... The learned Judges on this view allowed the appeal and upheld the provisional joint seniority list of, PCMS Class I showing respondents Nos. 3 to 19 above Dr. Jagjit Singh and the, appellant in seniority.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds the joint seniority list giving seniority to Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 over appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh from 8th April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were entitled to be placed senior to Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant in the joint seniority list of the integrated PCMS Class 1. We, therefore, uphold the joint seniority list of the integrated PCMS Class I prepared by the State Government giving seniority to respondents Nos. 3 to 19 over Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant and dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: Continuous service of Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 in PCMS Class I reckoned from 8th April 1964, date of appointment order with immediate effect.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, obvious that so far as respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were companycerned, the date of their appointment was 8th April, 1964 and the length of their companytinuous service in PCMS Class I was required to be reckoned from that date.

facts.text: Continuous service of appellant and Dr. Jagjit Singh in Public Health Service Class I commenced on 25th April 1964.

anchor.surface_text: since that was longer than the companytinuous service of Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant in Public Health Service Class I, which companymenced only on 25th April, 1964

facts.text: Appellant claimed seniority over Respondents Nos. 3 to 19 based on continuous service from 25th April 1964 versus their assumption of charge after that date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that on the basis of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii  of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 he was entitled to seniority over respondents Nos. 3 to 19 since his companytinuous service started from 25th April, 1964, while the companytinuous service of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 did number start until after 25th April, 1964 when they assumed charge of their respective posts.

facts.text: Post of District Medical Officer of Health was in Class II of Public Health Service; Assistant Director Health Services in Class I.

anchor.surface_text: The post of District Medical Officer of Health was a post in Class 11 of the Public Health Service, while the post of Assistant Director Health Services was a post in Class I of that Service.

facts.text: On integration, cadre of District Medical Officers of Health equated with PCMS Class II; Assistant/Deputy Directors with PCMS Class I.

anchor.surface_text: The cadre of District Medical Officers of Health, which companystituted Class 11 in Public Health Service was equated with PCMS Class 11 cadre, while the cadre of Assistant Directors and Deputy Directors, which companystituted Class I of Public Health Service, was equated with PCMS Class I cadre.

facts.text: Director, Health Services, Punjab communicated the seniority principle to appellant by letter dated 27th October 1964.

anchor.surface_text: This principle for determination of inter se seniority was companymunicated by the Director, Health Services, Punjab to the appellant in a letter dated 27th October, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant opted for integration in PCMS Class I.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was given an option in regard to integration in PCMS Class I and was told that on receipt of his opinion his seniority in PCMS Class I would be fixed in accordance with the length of his companytinuous service from the date of his appointment. The appellant opted in favour of integration and he was ac- companydingly, as stated above, integrated in PCMS Class 1.

facts.text: Dr. Jagjit Singh was on deputation with Defence Department.

anchor.surface_text: So far as Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant are companycerned, Dr. Jagjit Singh was on deputation with the Defence Department
Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and order dated the 8th April, 1970 of the Punjab Haryana High Court in P.A. No. 433/1969. R. L. Iyengar, S. K. Mehta for the appellant. R. Khanna and O.

issues.text: This appeal raises the question whether the appellant has been given his proper rank in the joint seniority list of officers belonging to the Provincial Civil Medical Service, Class I after its reorganisation on 15th July, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI, J.-This appeal raises the question whether the appellant has been given his proper rank in the joint seniority list of officers belonging to the Provincial Civil Medical Service, Class I after its reorganisation on 15th July, 1964.

issues.text: We must consider what was the true scope and ambit of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965. Did it apply in relation to officers coming from both services for the purpose of determining their inter se seniority in the integrated service or was it intended to provide a principle for determining seniority only for Deputy Directors and Assistant Directors on their integration in PCMS Class I?

anchor.surface_text: That led to the filing of the present appeal with special leave obtained from this Court. We must consider what was the true scope and ambit of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965. Did it apply in relation to officers coming from both services for the purpose of determining their inter se seniority in the integrated service or was it intended to provide a principle for determining seniority only for Deputy Directors and Assistant Directors on their integration in PCMS Class I ?

issues.answer: applies to officers from both services

issues.text: But the question then arises whether the State Government could issue the order dated 4th December, 1967 providing that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date of issue of their order of appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 irrespective as to when they assumed charge of the higher posts, if such order was in contravention of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, competent to the State Government to issue clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 in exercise of its executive power laying down the principle to be followed in adjusting inter se seniority of the officers in the integrated service. But the question then arises whether the State Government could issue the order dated 4th December, 1967 providing that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date of issue of their order of appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 irrespective as to when they assumed charge of the higher posts, if such order was in contravention of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965.

issues.text: Whether the order dated 4th December, 1967 providing that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date of their appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 constituted a departure from the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: If, therefore, we find that the order dated 4th December, 1967 gave an artificial date from which the continuous service of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be deemed to have commenced, though in fact and in truth their continuous service commenced from different dates and it was thus in contravention of the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965, it would have to be held to be void as being violative of articles 14 and 16.

issues.text: First let us see what the words date of the order of appointment mean. Are they synonymous with date of the order of appointment? ... What is the date of appointment in case of an order appointing with immediate effect?

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that continuous service in a post could commence only when the incumbent took charge of the post and not earlier and, therefore, though respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were promoted under the order dated 8th April, 1964, their continuous service 1 359 U.S. 535 at 546-5473 Law. Sd. Second Series 1012. in the posts of promotion in PCMS Class I did not commence until after 25th April, 1964 when they took charge of their respective posts of promotion and hence the length of their continuous service in PCMS Class I was less than that of Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant in Public Health Service, Class 1. This contention is fallacious in that it fails to give sufficient importance to the words from the date of appointment and ignores the true meaning and effect of the order dated 8th April, 1964. First let us see what the words date of the order of appointment mean.

anchor.surface_text: First let us see what the words date of the order of appointment mean. Are they synonymous with date of the order of appointment ? We think number. An order of appointment may be of three kinds. It may appoint a person with effect from the date he assumes charge of the post or it may appoint him with immediate effect or it may appoint him simpliciter without saying as to when the appointment shall take effect.

holdings.text: There can, therefore, be no doubt that on a proper interpretation of clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 the principle of length of continuous service from the date of appointment was applicable to officers coming from both the services for the purpose of fixing their inter se seniority in the integrated service.

anchor.surface_text: There can, therefore, be no doubt that on a proper interpretation of clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965 the principle of length of continuous service from the date of appointment was applicable to officers coming from both the services for the purpose of fixing their inter se seniority in the integrated service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation based on context of integration problem requiring fair inter se seniority adjustment between officers from both services; proviso protects existing parent seniority but principle governs across services.

holdings.text: Where the State Government departs from a principle of seniority laid down by it, albeit by administrative instructions, and the departure is without reason and arbitrary, it would directly infringe the guarantee of equality under articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: Where the State Government departs from a principle of seniority laid down by it, albeit by administrative instructions, and the departure is without reason and arbitrary, it would directly infringe the guarantee of equality under articles 14 and 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative instructions issued under executive power are binding; arbitrary departure lacks rationality, violates Art 14/16 equality; supported by precedents like B.N. Nagarajan and Sant Ram Sharma.

holdings.text: We do not, however, think that the order dated 4th December, 1967 providing that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date of their appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 constituted a departure from the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, think that the order dated 4th December, 1967 providing that the seniority of respondents Nos. 3 to 19 shall be reckoned from the date of their appointment, namely, 8th April, 1964 constituted a departure from the principle of seniority laid down in clause 2 ii of the memorandum dated 25th October, 1965.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order correctly applies principle by properly interpreting 'date of appointment'; no artificial fixation as service reckoned from actual effective date per order terms.

holdings.text: In a case [...] where the order appoints with immediate effect, the appointment would be effective immediately irrespective as to when the person appointed assumes charge of the post. The date of his appointment in such a case would be the same as the date of the order of appointment.

anchor.surface_text: First let us see what the words date of the order of appointment mean. Are they synonymous with date of the order of appointment ? We think no. An order of appointment may be of three kinds. It may appoint a person with effect from the date he assumes charge of the post or it may appoint him with immediate effect or it may appoint him simpliciter without saying as to when the appointment shall take effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis distinguishes three types of appointment orders; for 'immediate effect', effective date is order date regardless of charge assumption; continuous service deemed from that date.

holdings.text: It is, therefore, obvious that so far as respondents Nos. 3 to 19 were concerned, the date of their appointment was 8th April, 1964 and the length of their continuous service in PCMS Class I was required to be reckoned from that date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of interpreted 'date of appointment' to facts of 8th April 1964 order with immediate effect; service continuous from order date despite later charge assumption.

We, therefore, uphold the joint seniority list of the integrated PCMS Class I prepared by the State Government giving seniority to respondents Nos. 3 to 19 over Dr. Jagjit Singh and the appellant and dismiss the appeal.

Seton 1  This view is of companyrse number based on the equality clause of the United State Constitution and it is evolved as a rule of administrative law.

anchor.surface_text: Where the State Government departs from a principle of seniority laid down by it, albeit by administrative instructions, and the departure is without reason and arbitrary, it would directly infringe the guarantee of equality under articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: First let us see what the words date of the order of appointment mean. Are they synonymous with date of the order of appointment ? We think no. An order of appointment may be of three kinds. It may appoint a person with effect from the date he assumes charge of the post or it may appoint him with immediate effect or it may appoint him simpliciter without saying as to when the appointment shall take effect.
We, therefore, uphold the joint seniority list of the integrated PCMS Class I prepared by the State Government giving seniority to respondents Nos. 3
